newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: GE-P&W says close to Airbus superjumbo engine deal.
newsitem.headline: GE-P&W says close to Airbus superjumbo engine deal.

text.p: The president of U.S. aero-engine joint venture GE-P&W Engine Alliance said on Tuesday the group was close to a memorandum of understanding with the European Airbus Industrie consortium to supply superjumbo engines.
"We are in the final stages of an MOU with Airbus and expect it within days or weeks, and certainly before the end of the year," Larry Scott told reporters at the Seoul Air Show.

GE Aircraft Engines, a unit of General Electric, and United Technologies Corp unit Pratt and Whitney teamed up to build an engine for Boeing Co's 747-500X and 600X planes, which are bigger versions of the 747 jumbo.
GE Aircraft Engines said last month it would offer European Airbus Industrie the engine if the consortium builds its 3XX superjumbo, which would seat more than 500 passengers.

Scott said the engine to be offered to European Airbus, a GP7277 with 78,000 pounds of thrust, was in the final design stages. It would begin the certification process in January 1997, and start testing in 1998.
Certification was expected by the end of 1999, and the engines could be supplied before 2000.
The engine was part of the new GP7000 family of powerplants, Scott said.
Scott forecast the global superjumbo market at between 500 and 1,200 planes. He did not give a timeframe.

"Seventy percent of those will be delivered to the Asia/Pacific market. These planes haul large numbers of people long distances and this is an opportunity market for this type of aircraft," he added.
